text: hello I'm David Pogue New York Times
technology columnist now I'll be the
first to admit that I love technology I
love the magic of it I love the snow I
love when the FedEx man rings my
doorbell and hands me an armload full of
present I mean um technology products to
review but I'll also admit that there
are a few things I don't like so much
about technology I hate waiting for my
rebate checks to arrive
hate running out of one color cartridge
when I'm on a deadline and all the
stores are closed and I hate just trying
to find a place to plug everything in
but you know what drives me crazy as to
ball voicemail all the cell carrier
wants to do is get you to run up your
bill I swear to god this is me checking
my voicemail you have seven new messages
you have two saved messages to listen to
your messages press one when you are
finished you may hang up or press 5 for
more options to hear this message again
press six to use up more airtime for no
reason at all that's nine to exit this
message press a knife to your wrists
nada this week in the times I found out
about two new services to let me fight
back with technology one's called spin
box the other is called Simon escribe
both of them exist to turn the audio of
voicemail messages left for you in turn
to text that gets sent to you by email
or sent as text messages to your phone
the accuracy is good enough meanwhile
it's just so sweet to be able to skim a
text message instead of having to sit
through the audio plus you have random
access to the messages so you can skip
the unimportant ones and you never have
to copy down phone numbers or driving
instructions because they've already
been copied down post office box you
want to go right not left there but then
bear right at the fort go down about
three blocks will see the house on the
left only Simon scribe includes the
audio of beach
message right in the body of the email
so you can check the parts are not sure
of and only sign will strive offers this
cool website where all your messages
show up but Simas tribe is also
expensive ten dollars a month for 40
messages spin box on the other hand is
free during its one-year us trial after
that you'll have to sign up for it
directly through your cell carrier
pricing to be announced anyway that's
one high tech annoyance gone forever now
all I have to do is find a way to open
those damned clear kryptonite packages
better
